issues.description: The problem statement (and template Main.java comments/UML) require concrete animal classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat. The solution repository, however, does not provide implementations for Seal, Pig, and Goat (those files are empty) and instead provides implementations named SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This class-name / type mismatch is structural: students following the problem will implement Seal/Pig/Goat, but the solution uses differently named types. This can confuse students (which class names are canonical?) and will break any tests or references that expect Seal, Pig, and Goat to be implemented with the specified behavior and constructors.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution repository match the problem specification: provide concrete implementations named Seal, Pig, and Goat (each extending Animal and implementing the appropriate interfaces) with the constructors and message methods described in the problem. Alternatively, if SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat are intentional, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main.java to refer to those exact class names (and adjust example messages accordingly) so all artifacts use the same type names.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template refer to animal classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat (the UML and Main.java use these names). The solution repository instead implements these animals as SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This naming divergence means students cannot directly map the problem's required class names to the solution implementation. It also causes the animal-type text in messages to show the 'Space' prefix (e.g. 'SpaceSeal Clarabelle is milked') rather than the expected 'Seal Clarabelle is milked', which breaks the clear correspondence between the UML/problem description and the provided solution code.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the animal class names in the solution with the problem/template by providing classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat. Options: (a) Rename SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat to Seal/Pig/Goat and update their constructors/message strings accordingly; or (b) add small wrapper classes Seal, Pig, Goat that extend or delegate to SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat so the expected names exist. Also, make the milk/ride message strings derive the animal type from getClass().getSimpleName() (or otherwise use the exact class name) so outputs match the expected '[Animal Type] [name] is milked' / 'Riding on [Animal Type] [name]'. This preserves the UML/problem naming and removes the student mapping confusion.
